texts.shortText:
As a group syllid species are fairly easily to recognise, as most are long, thin worms with unusually elongate, often annulated cirri projecting from each segment.

This long, thin and attractively coloured species has an transparent-white body bearing distinctive bright orange patches along the back. The head bears two pairs of round black eyes, three elongate antennae and two pairs of long tentacular cirri. The parapodia (lateral appendages) of the following body segments bear large sail-like dorsal cirri that curl over the back. Many individuals carry a chain of developing sexual buds from their posterior ends.

Global: Endemic to southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibia to Cape Peninsula.
Usually solitary and found crawling rapidly on the undersides of boulders in intertidal pool. All members of this group are predatory.
Details unknown for this species, but some other members of this genus are reported to feed on ascidians by piercing the zooids and sucking out the contents.

Members of this family are famous for their diversity of reproductive strategies. Some species have a specialised pelagic phase in the lifecycle which swims off the bottom and release the eggs and sperm into the plankton. Others bud-off baby individuals (stolons) which detach from the parent and swim away to establish themselves at another site. Another variation is to develop a single reproductive stolon, which has enlarged appendages and swims off in to the plankton, where is bursts and dies. This species is commonly observed to bear a chain of developing buds extending from the tail end.

The family contains about 60 regional species and many of these are difficult to distinguish without microscopic examination of the setae on the parapodia and shape and number of annulations of the cirri. The colour pattern of this species is immediately identifiable though.

Augener, H (1918). Polychaeta. Beitrage zur Kenntnis der Meeresfauna Westafrikas, 2(2), 67-625 (original description).

Day, JH (1967). A Monograph on the Polychaeta of Southern Africa. British Museum (Natural History), London, Part 2. (p. 287).

Nygren, A (2004). Revision of Autolytinae (Syllidae: Polychaeta). Zootaxa, 680, 1-314.
